Award.AwardTitle: Phase II I/UCRC University of Wisconsin-Milwaukee: Center for Grid-connected Advanced Power Electronic Systems (GRAPES)
Award.AbstractNarration:
University of Wisconsin-Milwaukee (UWM) is requesting to join an existing Phase Two I/UCRC center, Grid-connected Advanced Power Electronic Systems (GRAPES), which was established in 2009 with University of Arkansas as a lead and University of South Carolina as a site. The GRAPES has been providing significant benefits to the members and nation through advancing the knowledge in grid-connected power electronics and developing intellectual properties. The goal of the UWM site is to supplement and complement the existing expertise, capabilities, and facilities to better achieve mission of GRAPES to accelerate the adoption and insertion of power electronics into the grid in order to improve system stability, flexibility, robustness, and economy. UWM will add another geographical area and population center, diversity, cutting edge facilities of power electronics, microgrids, protection, energy efficiency, and energy storage into GRAPES. Milwaukee has traditionally been one of the largest power electronics hubs in the nation, home to many large and medium power companies. Majority of focus at the proposed UWM site will be on distributed generation integration, AC and DC Microgrids, distribution and protection, ancillary services, smart distribution, grid connected energy storage systems, and SiC-based converters. UWM will bring Midwest market and region to GRAPES. The facilities include a 350 kVA microgrid system, center for sustainable electrical energy systems, energy storage systems and interface, test setups for high voltage wide band gap devices, DC protection setups. UWM faculty expertise in converter level wide band gap devices, fault and protection, power electronics systems, energy efficiency, power electronics reliability, and integration of distributed generation greatly support the existing activities and capabilities at GRAPES.

University of Wisconsin-Milwaukee (UWM) will join an existing Phase Two I/UCRC center, Grid-connected Advanced Power Electronic Systems (GRAPES). The objectives of GRAPES are three folds: (i) develop advanced technologies for grid-connected power electronics, power distribution, and smart loads, (ii) develop software and embedded controls for power electronics converters and systems, and (iii) develop workforce for the power and energy conversion and control industry. A group of four core faculty and a larger group of affiliated faculty at UWM with extensive experience and expertise in power electronics converters, controls, and systems, and strong support from industry will conduct cutting edge research on design, modeling, simulation, implementation, and testing of grid-connected power electronics devices and systems. The goal is to increase the penetration of power electronics into utility grid at all levels of generation, distribution, and smart load, in order to increase efficiency, reliability, sustainability, and to lower cost. UWM site will mainly focus on distributed generation integration, AC and DC Microgrids, distribution and protection, ancillary services, smart distribution, grid connected energy storage systems, and SiC-based converters. The main broader impact is to provide the highest quality integrated education, research, and engineering to meet the emerging workforce and needs of the nation?s energy industry. To conduct research, team members including professors, graduate and undergraduate students, and industry experts will collaborate. UWM GRAPES site will have broader impacts at many levels: high school students, UWM students, working professionals, minority and underrepresented groups, and member companies. Research results from projects will be integrated with courses for students and will be disseminated to industry through monthly webinars, semi-annual meetings, short courses, and publications. The center activities will also have profound impacts on the energy conversion and controls industry in Wisconsin and broader Midwest by developing new technologies and intellectual properties.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The major goal of this project has been to establish and sustain a site for Grid-connected Advanced Power Electronic Systems (GRAPES) I/UCRC center at the University of Wisconsin-Milwaukee (UWM). The site at UWM joined University of Arkansas (UA) in this center. UWM faculty and GRAPES industry partners conduct cutting edge research in the center on various aspects of grid-connected power electronics systems including interface for distributed generations, interface for energy storage systems, AC and DC microgrids, protection and electromagnetic compatibility, and power electronics cybersecurity and resilience. The primary objectives of the Center are:

  • “To develop new technologies for advanced power electronic systems in the areas supporting grid connected distributed energy resources, power steering and routing devices, and intelligent load-side devices,
  • To develop the software and tools for controlling embedded- and grid-connected power electronics to benefit the grid as well as controlled loads,
  • To educate engineers who understand the power electronic technologies important to the member companies and the nation.”

The site at the University of Wisconsin-Milwaukee (UWM) shares the same focus but has added emphasis on other applications including grid integration of distributed generations, AC and DC microgrids, packaging of WBG systems operating at high frequencies for Electromagnetic Compatibility (EMC), microgrid protection and interface for energy storage systems. Major impacts on the field of energy conversion include the followings:

- Advancing the field of high frequency and high power magnetics by developing high frequency solid state transformers and multiport solid state transformers.

- Advancing the field of energy storage systems and energy storage converters.

- Advancing the field of microgrid controls by developing the concept for distributed microgrid controls, developing hardware in the loop setup, and validating the results.

- Advancing the field of electromagnetic interference compatibility for high frequency SiC-based converters by modeling the conducted emissions, design filters, and validating performances.

- Advancing the field of fault management of hybrid AC/DC systems by quantifying faults, managements, grounding, and developing hardware in the loop platforms for testing.

- Advancing the field of networked microgrids by designing robust controls and energy management.

- More importantly, GRAPES trains students and postdocs in this critical field on various high impact projects. GRAPES graduates are highly marketable as they gain experience on real industry related and industry sponsored projects.

GRAPES is now the largest power electronics research entity in the country in terms of number of participating faculty and researchers. A major outcome of UWM joining GRAPES is that power electronics research and education at UWM has been elevated to a national level. The power electronics team at UWM is now much larger with four participating faculty and includes other faculty in controls and machine learning, several postdoc fellows, and many undergraduate and graduate students. Close collaborations with industry members have been enriching the research programs and have enabled UWM to study short term and long term challenges that face the power electronics and energy conversion industry. The results of the research projects have been published in numerous reputable journals and have been presented at many peer-reviewed technical conferences.

The main broader impact has been to provide the highest quality integrated education, research, and engineering to meet the emerging workforce and needs of the nation’s energy industry. To conduct research, team members including professors, graduate and undergraduate students, and industry experts have been collaborating. UWM GRAPES site has had and will have broader impacts at many levels: high school students, UWM students, working professionals, minority and underrepresented groups, and member companies. Research results from projects have been integrated with courses for students and are disseminated to industry through monthly webinars, semi-annual meetings, short courses, and publications. The center activities also have profound impacts on the energy conversion and controls industry in Wisconsin and broader Midwest by developing new technologies and intellectual properties. Several courses have been updated with the research results from the GRAPES project including Power Electronics, Advanced Power Electronics, Controls for renewable Energy, and Electromagnetic Compatibility (EMC). Many students and postdoctoral fellows have also been trained in the GRAPES center.

The conducted projects have also impacted the field of energy storage systems and electrical distribution systems. As part of the GRAPES projects, high power battery storage systems for variety of applications including renewable energy support, pulse load, and grid support have been modeled, tested, and developed. In addition, various power electronics-based devices and converter to convert the legacy electrical distribution systems to smart distribution systems have been designed and applied. Further, GRAPES projects are using both controls and artificial intelligence (machine learning) for control and optimization of energy systems. Faculty with expertise in control systems and artificial intelligence are working on distribution systems and multi-objective optimization of energy systems to reduce component size and cost and improve efficiency and sustainability.
